title: PiGRRL Zero - Modified for Speakers and Standoff Screws!

description.text:
[EDIT] - Please note how I have setup my three prong potentiometer and know that how I got mine to work was hooking the ground to one of the outside poles, and the other two speaker wires next to each other.

This is a modification of the PiGRRL Zero case w/ a couple different modifications. I've built three of these handhelds now, and have made some changes that will make the device a much better fit for closure and usability. Here is a list of the tweaks made to the original design for both cases:

  • Widen both cases horizontally 5mm to allow room for PCB and Adafruit screen/Pi Zero ~ I found that the clearance was tight with the SD card
  • Deepen top case 2mm to allow for more room internally and proper closure at the top of the cases
  • Reduce height to PCB screw pegs 0.1mm to make tighter buttons when installing the PCB's

See the photos above to compare version 2 of this case with the original PiGRRL Zero case that was designed by Adafruit.

Version 1 - Just the case enlargements
Version 2 - Modifications above and speakers, amplifier and potentiometer(volume)!
Version 2.1 - Same as version 2, just modified placements for large battery sizes
Version 3 - Version 2, but with recessed standoffs for screws providing stable gameplay
Version 3.1 - Same as version 2.1, but with standoff screws

If you follow the Adafruit tutorial to build your PiGRRL Zero, you want to use Version 3 only. 3.1 is just a different variation that will work for you, but only for those who have a larger battery. 3.1 works, but 3.0 is really the best balance for the case.

Please note that version 3 and 3.1 with standoffs is going to require you to cut the top corner of your PCB gamepads. Don't worry, they shouldn't have any purpose or need up in the corner of those gamepads, as all the electronic components are lower.

For version 2 & 3, here are the components I used to get this working:

Adafruit MAX98357 I2S Class-D Mono Amp (https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-max98357-i2s-class-d-mono-amp/overview)

Adafruit Mini Metal Speaker w/ Wires - 8 ohm 0.5W (https://www.adafruit.com/product/1890)

16mmx2mm 10K ohm Stereo Volume Control Wheel Potentiometer B103 (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00O9Y766Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

(NEW!) Adafruit Provides the quiet buttons now! - https://www.adafruit.com/products/3101

I have the external audio working, but you will need to reconfigure some buttons first to get the hook ups working for I2S. I've been working with Thanos on the Adafruit forums who seems to have it going and working correctly. Here is a link to the post on the forums (https://forums.adafruit.com/viewtopic.php?f=50&t=97961) and I have also attached a PDF tutorial of how to get this all working. (Kudos to Thanos again for posting the IMG file of the changes he made to make it easy on us!)

Let me know if you have any modifications or thoughts on this case. I have it setup in Fusion 360, so it's a quick change and modification to the case if anyone has any suggestions.

If you want me to print you a case, go ahead and hit me up on my Etsy shop. I've already got this setup and tuned to print very nice versions of this case. If you have a certain color you want, just submit an order and I'll pick up some filament. If you want me to build one for you, hit me up on my Etsy shop. I have a open order that you can purchase one and I'll assemble it, with the color you want.

https://www.etsy.com/shop/3dprintspace

Check out my multicolor button for the PiGRRL Zero and Zero Plus if you are interested in that - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368254

description.text:
This is a modification of bqLabs CiClop 3D Scanner. I have changed it to accommodate a Raspberry Pi in place of the Arduino. I have not completed the electrical circuit or software.
Sketchup files are included.

Laser Mount

  • relocated the nut so that it inserts from inside of the laser mounting hole this provides more material around the nut and makes it easier to remove if needed
  • use an M3 bolt and nut

Turn Table Base

  • removed the M8 nut traps, the original design did not allow for easy adjustment of the M8 bolt lengths, I have changed the design so that you can adjust this easier, I did recess the nuts on one side - you will need a socket for these
  • added clips that bolt (25mm M5 hex bolts and nuts) in place to hold the bearing, these have nut traps on the underside acccessed from where the motor mounts
  • removed foot locators
  • removed all the extra supports (they are not needed for printing), the only supports are for the motor shaft and bolts and the bearing mount bolts, these are easily cleaned with a drillbit and knife

Table Plate

  • had to increase some of the dimensions slightly to accomodate the bearing better (probably due to my printer capabilities)
  • increased the volume around the shaft coupling socket, I found that the original design was prone to layer separation when the part was twisted
  • I removed the supports for the bearing clips and print them on their side (no supports needed)
  • there are supports in the bolt holes that will need to be cleaned out with a drillbit
  • use three button head M6 25mm bolts and nuts to mount

Case

  • modified to fit a Raspberry Pi
  • the case is split into two pieces so that they can be printed on smaller beds
  • the pieces are bolted together, use two M5 20mm hex bolts and nuts to attach the top to the base (there are nut traps accessed from the inside of the top housing)
  • the Raspberry Pi is held in place with two printed spring clips
  • I removed all the extra supports from the original, print the case pieces face down, no addition supports should be needed
  • the lid should be printed on end, I use an extra wide brim to give support against bed motion
  • four 12mm M3 bolts and nuts to mount the cover, the nuts slide into a but trap in the main housing (be sure to clear the holes of supports first using a drillbit)

Shaft Coupling

  • used the original as-is

print_settings.Notes:: Colsonbot was printed in ABS using a Dimension 1200ES, but has also been printed in PLA and Nylon. 100% fill, or sparse fill with many shells, should be used for strength. Most important areas for strength is the central tower that supports the 5/8" bolt.

description.text:
Colsonbot, Colsonbot
Does whatever a colsonbot does
Can he spin? Can he win?
NO HE CAN'T!
He's a wheel!

Colsonbot is a 3lb weight class ("Beetleweight") combat robot that lives in an 8" caster wheel (hence the Colson name). It's a quick, maneuverable shell-spinner design with a brushless friction-drive system for the shell, that could be quite competitive if only it didn't live inside a wheel. Colsonbot is a pacifist, nonviolent combat robot. Perfect for FIRST Robotics.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

90 to 100%

Notes:

Colsonbot was printed in ABS using a Dimension 1200ES, but has also been printed in PLA and Nylon. 100% fill, or sparse fill with many shells, should be used for strength. Most important areas for strength is the central tower that supports the 5/8" bolt.

Assembly Instructions

Colsonbot uses the following parts:

  • QTY 4: Fingertech Robotics Silver Spark 11:1
  • QTY 4: McMaster-Carr P/N 9600K53 rubber grommets
  • QTY 2: Vex Robotics 29 Motor Controller
  • QTY 1: Hobbyking Zippy 1000mah 3S/25C LiPoly battery
  • QTY 1 or 2: Hobbyking NTM PROPDRIVE 2830 motor
  • QTY 1 or 2: Hobbyking TURNIGY PLUS 18A brushless motor controller

Use flathead #4 x 3/8" coarse-thread sheet metal screws, or Plastite/threadforming screws for plastic to assemble the covers.

To use a 8"x2" Colson Performa wheel as the spinning shell, it must be machined hollow using a lathe. A size PFR-2214 bearing, 5/8" bore, fits into the wheel center. The part "Spacer for PFR-2214 Bearing" is to space out the bearings axially (along the center shaft) only.

The center shaft is made using a 5/8"-18 hex-head bolt whose head is machined down to 1/8" thickness.

A full report of Colsonbot's build can be found here: http://www.etotheipiplusone.net/?p=3718

description.text:
In search of a fan duct for my Kossel XL, I found the Mini Kossel E3D V6 Effector & 30mm Duct fan (thing:1373201). I like it, because it is compact and cools the hotend as well as the object. It does not blow against the hotend as some other fan ducts do, in my opinion that is a good thing. I could not use it unmodified however, because my hotend has a vulcano heater block, which makes it a bit longer. Using Tinkercad, I modified the design to fit my E3D v6 with vulcano heater block. The aluminium end effector, visible in the photo's, was bought at robotdigg.

Link to the Tinkercad page:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3E2fQNgtfsp-e3d-v6-vulcano-fan-duct

I created a simple model of the bridges using available profile pictures of the bridges.

Project Name

Bridge Building: Understanding bridge construction and compete to make the strongest bridge.

Overview & Background

Students will learn about different types of bridges and the principles of engineering used to design bridges.

Objectives:
  • Identify different types of bridges
  • Identify effective geometric shapes used in bridge design
  • Identify factors that engineers consider when designing bridges
  • Explain the following fundamental structural engineering concepts:
    force, load, reaction, equilibrium, tension, compression, and strength
  • Explain how a bridge works—how each individual component contributes to the ability of the entire structure to carry a load
  • Explain how construction quality affects the performance of a structure

    • Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry
  • CONTENT STANDARD B: Physical Science
    As a result of their activities, all students should develop understanding of
    • Motions and forces
  • CONTENT STANDARD E: Science and Technology
    As a result of activities, all students should develop
    • Abilities of technological design
    • Understandings about science and technology
  • CONTENT STANDARD F: Science in Personal and Social Perspectives
    As a result of activities, all students should develop understanding of
    • Science and technology in local, national, and global challenges
  • CONTENT STANDARD G: History and Nature of Science
    As a result of activities, all students should develop understanding of
    • Historical perspectives

Next Generation Science Standards Grades 3-5 (Ages 8-11)

  • Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
    Students who demonstrate understanding can:
    • 3-PS2-1. Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence of the effects
      of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object.
  • Engineering Design
    Students who demonstrate understanding can:
    • 3-5-ETS1-1.Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that
      includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or
      cost.
    • 3-5-ETS1-2.Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem
      based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the
      problem.
    • 3-5-ETS1-3.Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and
      failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that
      can be improved.

Next Generation Science Standards Grades 6-8 (Ages 11-14)

  • Engineering Design
    Students who demonstrate understanding can:
    • MS-ETS1-1 Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with
      sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account
      relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural
      environment that may limit possible solutions.
    • MS-ETS1-2 Evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process
      to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

Standards for Technological Literacy - All Ages

  • The Nature of Technology
    • Standard 1: Students will develop an understanding of the characteristics and scope of technology.
  • Technology and Society
    • Standard 4: Students will develop an understanding of the cultural, social,
      economic, and political effects of technology.
    • Standard 5: Students will develop an understanding of the effects of
      technology on the environment.
    • Standard 6: Students will develop an understanding of the role of society in
      the development and use of technology.
    • Standard 7: Students will develop an understanding of the influence of technology on history.
  • Design
    • Standard 8: Students will develop an understanding of the attributes of
      design.
    • Standard 9: Students will develop an understanding of engineering design.
    • Standard 10: Students will develop an understanding of the role of
      troubleshooting, research and development, invention and innovation, and
      experimentation in problem solving.
  • Abilities for a Technological World
    • Standard 11: Students will develop abilities to apply the design process.
  • The Designed World
    • Standard 20: Students will develop an understanding of and be able to select
      and use construction technologies.
Lesson/Activity:
  • 3D print the mini bridges to use as a training aid
  • Discuss different types of bridges
    • Arch
    • Beam
    • Cantilever
    • Suspension
    • Truss
    • Cable Stayed
  • Discuss geometry
    • Pentagon
    • Square
    • Triangle
  • Discuss physics
    • Force
    • Load
    • Reaction
    • Equilibrium
    • Tension
    • Compression
    • Strength
  • Factors that engineers consider when designing bridges
    • Structural efficiency
    • Cost efficiency
    • Aesthetics
  • Guide students through selecting/creating a bridge model, either work in teams or individually. Set bridge specifications and constraints, these will depend on your time and resources:
    • Minimum length width and length of bridge
    • Maximum amount of filament to be used to 3D print the bridge
    • Minimum amount of weight the bridge is to hold
    • If the bridge is allowed to be assembled parts of 3d printed as one piece
  • Students 3D print and assemble their bridge
  • Supervise and assess students testing bridge
Duration:
  • Print the 3D components – Various Timings
  • Describe various types of bridges and design features – 1 day Theory Lesson
  • Students create a bridge using CAD - 5 days Practical Lesson
  • Students 3D print their bridge – Various Timings
  • Student test their bridge design – 30mins Practical Lesson
Preparation:

Resources:

  • 3D filament
  • 3D Printer
  • Computer with access to Thingiverse
  • Computer with access to CAD software

Knowledge:

  • Basic writing and numeracy is required
  • The ability to read and interpret typical product specifications, job sheets and material labels as provided to operators.
References:

Article: Bridges Wikipedia page

Rubric & Assessment:

By the end of the project the student will have a designed, 3D printed, and tested a bridge.
Assessment Criteria:

  • Did the students bridge meet the minimum requirements:
    • Length
    • Width
    • Hold minimum weight
    • Did not exceed the maximum allocation of 3D printer filament
  • Can the student identify features of their bridge:
    • Type of bridge
    • Use of geometric shapes
    • Locate points of force, load, reaction, equilibrium, tension, compression, and strength

title: Propane Cylinder Valve Handle and Cap

description.text:
One of the first things I designed was a handle-adaptor for a propane cylinder. The guys where i get my cylinders filled always close the valve so tight that I cannot loosen it with my arthritic hands. This new handle just fits over the existing handle and allows for a more ergonomic grip which lets me open the valve.

The cap was mostly just for the challenge of creating something in Fusion 360 which I have just started learning to use.

The handle, designed in 123d Design prints well and fits the valve handle fine though not perfect.

The cap, on the other hand, works but there is some anomaly that leaves some stringing that has to be trimmed and it screws on the valve threads a little tight. I’m okay with it because it works satisfactorily, but wanted to give you a heads-up so you wouldn’t think it was something wrong with your printer.

Both the cap and the handle were run through Microsoft’s Model Repair Service so I’ve done the best I can with my limited knowledge.

Printrbot

title: M Prime One - Carriage with blower fan

description.text:
Description

Following the same principles of M Prime, I have designed this carriage that allows to put radial fans. These are found to blow more air, which ultimately improves printing quality.
It is meant to hold the given capacitive sensor and hot end but replaces the axial fan by a radial fan. This is fixed with a screw and the air is guided with an extra part. I specifically designed this for my fan and the E3D v6 Little but could be used with other standard fans and hot ends.

BOM

There are three parts:

  • Carriage: which, oh surprise, is the carriage.
  • Hot end holder: the part that fixes the hot end to the carriage
  • Blower commander: designed for 50mm fans and the E3D v6 Little.
  • 50mm radial fan
  • E3D v6 Little
  • 2x M3x20
  • 4x M3x10

How to

Follow your instinct. If I did it you can do it too! :P

Firmware

As the position of the Z probe changes with respect to the hot end, the firmware must be change accordingly to have a reliable autoleveling.
My settings are 

  #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 24  // X offset: -left  [of the nozzle] +right
  #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 4  // Y offset: -front [of the nozzle] +behind
  #define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1.0   // Z offset: -below [the nozzle] (always negative!)

Printer:

M Prime One

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

remixed_from.title: Solidoodle Jigsaw Replacement Extruder mk5 - Bowden

description.text:
Modified Lawsy's mk5 bowden extruder part to capture a bowden connector so it can handler really high filament pressure.

Also made the filament path much more constrained, so this should work for flexible filaments like ninjaflex (untested).

The "die" is a piece that locks the bowden push-fit connector in place.

The file "extruder in progress plated.stl" contains both the die and the main piece, rotated for printing.

One of the key features of The Micro 3D printer is its compact design. It weighs only 1 kg! So it is the perfect printer to take with you, or carry around in the house. But it needed a handle...

Printer:

M3D's The Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low (0.3)

Infill:

Low

Notes:

This is a perfect application for M3D's Tough 3D Ink. The snap pins should be printed in standard PLA like 3D Ink.
Use this handle at your own risk!

The sliding door that allows access to my bedroom is hollow so the latch that someone has fastened to it with 4 screws, easily comes off as the 4 screws aren't anchored into anything more than 1/8" worth of hardboard and the rest is air.

So, I drilled out 5/16" holes where the screws were (all the way through the door) and inserted this thing from the opposite side and voila! I can now have it securely anchored to something and sleep better at night for it.

I also painted mine before install so that it looked metallic from the outside.

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

title: Bedini-Type 6-Pole Magnet Motor

description.text:
Based on the Bedini Pulse Motor Design (Free Energy/Overunity)
3-Part Design. (Base, Central Magnet Rotor, Outter Ring)

You're supposed to Fill the Center of the Coils with Iron Filings,
Glue Magnets to the Outside of the Rotor,
and Wrap the Coils with 1000+ winds of Wiring.

You'll need to glue a Bearing into the Center of the Rotor, so the rotor can Spin.
The base will also help the Rotor to Spin, and to hold everything together.

I even included an additional Coil/Spool model incase you want to Add more power output.

UPDATE - Added Outter Coil v2, that has pickup and drive wire holes in the Spools.

---Not to scale---
You will need to adjust the Size to Fit the Application.

Item is not For Sale, Royalty Free.
[ Do Not Sell nor Re-Distribute my Work ]

You're Welcome

author: Syrus54

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner  
This is a reproduction of a medieval style stone carving of a knight on a horse.  I got it on my honeymoon in Quebec many years ago.  
Flat reliefs can be challenging to scan.  This one is really very flat with a subtle carving.  The key to getting a good scan on something like this is to not place the object in the center of the table.  Instead, try offsetting it.  In this case after a few tests, I found the best scan was when I placed it a few inches forward.  I also painted it with some washable watered down tempera paint to get the laser to reflect well.  Scanned using the "dark" setting.  
I propped it up on a stack of boxes.  I included the original scan straight from Digitizer and a cleaned STL where I cut off the boxes and gave it a flat back if you want to try printing it horizontally, but it will probably print best vertically.

author: oldmatedave

description.text:
Jet Aerator - Live Bait Tank

This was designed to increase the dissolved oxygen in a live bait tank as two air stones could not sustain the travelling times and the bait would die.

Using the outlet of the bilge pump to flow over a single stone and create turbulent water by using internal veins to make the water rotate. The air hose will need to be sealed through the inlet as it may not be a perfect fit.

The air stone was purchased from a local pet shop, it has an OD of ~15.4mm and 21mm in length plus the tube the fitting.

Specs
Inlet - 19.6mm OD
Air Tubing - 3mm (Roughly 5-6mm external ID depending on pipe)
Air inlet hole - 6mm
Outlet - 14mm ID

Link to video - https://youtu.be/T-VDDm1I98M

Check out my other designs http://www.thingiverse.com/benny90/designs

title: Camera slider (motorized)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This camera slider is used for DSLR or system cameras but also for action cams.
You can use it with or without a motor driver.

Without motor driver, you need:

  • square tubes 15x15 mm aluminium (for round you have to make your own parts) (buy)
  • 4x tube mounts, bottom (option with M3 inserts) and top with M3 bolts (print)
    the "loose" one can be tightened with bolts, the "tighten" one can be used without bolts
  • bearingblock (4x), maybe it can with 3 parts (print)
  • bearings used are standard type 606 (6176 mm) (buy)
  • for mounting are used bolt M5x20 and M6x20 for the bearings
  • aluminium, plastic or wooden plate for mounting the bearing blocks (make)
  • camera bolt to mount your camera, depending on camera type (1/4") (buy)

For electronic slider you need the following added:

  • belt mounts to secure the belt, both parts to lock belt (print)
  • belt: type 2GT-6 about 2m length (buy)
  • belt pulley mount slider to tighten belt (2 parts print)
    see also: nutholder on mythings for the wingnuts
  • 2x aluminium pulley wheels (buy)
  • motor mount for belt pulley, with or without lipo case (print)
  • motor type Nema 17 Stepper Motor 42 motor 17HS8401 (buy)
  • electronic box with speed control:
    • pcb board with some wire (50x70 mm)
    • arduino nano with mini usb
    • digital encoder (ky-040)
    • 7-segment display (TM1637 LED display)
    • stepper driver board (A3967 EasyDriver Stepper Motor Driver)
    • on/off switch (optional)
    • 2 end-switches
    • power source plug (female jack 5.5 mm)
  • Arduino program will be included and electronic-schematics

See also on Instagram @DIYhans
If you have any questions, let me know.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYgCw06X8i4&feature=youtu.be

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the bearingblock raft and supports are adivised.
For the pulley mount slider top supports are advised.

comments.text:
I updated the slider with electronics and speedcontrol
Easy to assemble

title: Aesthetic Toilet Seat and Cover Hinge

description.text:
My first items uploaded to the world will be related to toilets... =|

Anyways this is a complete toilet hinge assembly and includes a base, base cover, axle and cover and seat anchors. These are printed at a loose tolerance because my printer prints ovals instead of circles. As a result you may want to adjust the axle scale to be more or less tight. Let me know if this is convenient for anyone.

I printed at 100% infill and a higher temp to ensure pla strength but I suspect 20% infill would do just fine as well.

Printer:

QUBD or Q3D Two Up Two-Up

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20% or 100%

Notes:

My printer needs these decimals because of imperial to metric conversion on the Z Axis. More than likely you will use normal metric for your layers like .35mm instead on .34925mm
All parts laid out and assembled. 3D printed replacement hinge vs original broken hinge.

Hey,
you scew the brackets to the two mount holes on the extruder. In an orientation so that the two free slots are vertical.

print_settings.Notes:: Very pleased with the outcome.

description.text:
Yet another Pi Bumper. I have found that others I have downloaded were challenged when it came to joining the two parts to hold the board. So I came up with this super simple idea which is handy if you have 3mm filament to hand. The short lengths of filament are used as fasteners.

I made the holes oversized, but it was still necessary to drill them out with a 3mm drill bit.

Works well, but please note that there is not enough room for a standard header if you are connecting to a breadboard. Maybe I'll try o do a mod later.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Lulzbot Cura quickprint - .2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

First time I have used the Cura slicer - normally use Simplify3D

Very pleased with the outcome.

Drill out the fixing holes to 3mm

Use a short length of 3mm filament to assemble.

The Pi board mounting holes are drilled to 2.5mm so they will need drilling as well.

OnShape

After a long break from designing, I returned to OnShape for the design. OnShape is a browser only design tool which seems pretty comprehensive. There is a free tier and you can create an unlimited number of public designs, plus 10 private designs on this tier. As far as I am aware, there are no other restrictions which would affect the amateur designer.

The design is public at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f45f3df28d995e9ba569d82f/w/3c3f48a18c8b0739db8bce84/e/b215a7bbb15c866eeec93289

and any OnShape member can copy.

Simple hook inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1367661 but made from scratch. It is designed as hook for towel so it cannot hold big weight but small holes can be used to hang something on it.
powered by 3D Slash!
Follow this link to edit in 3D!! https://www.3dslash.net/i.php?src=thingiverse&s=3becad47

I was getting fed up with the flimsy aluminum flags that came with my kit, so I decided to replace them! This Z Flag attaches to the X rod set screws. The next step is to lengthen the screws and add a spring to make the flag adjustable

-Print
-Unscrew set screws on left side of X carriage
-Slip screws through z flag
-Add two nuts
-Reattach
-Calibrate and print!

description.text:
Apex-like knife sharpener.

NB! You have to rotate models to print it properly by yourself..

UPDATED 07.07.2016: Replaced 2pcs Wear-Resisting SF-1 Self Lubricating Bearing Bushing with 1 LM8UU bearing. Y-axis part changed

To make that thing you need to buy:

  • 1pcs Ikea immeln hook, and put out metal part (hook itself). It has great suction cups to grip the desk.
  • 1pcs 8mm L200mm + 1pcs 8mm L500mm smooth rods. Such as in 3d printers. Length can some vary
  • 1pcs ~30-50mm length spring with inned dia 8-10mm. I didn't buy that, because I took it from my old Apex clone from aliexpress
  • 1pcs LM8UU bearing
  • 2pcs F624ZZ flanged bearings (4mm x 13mm x 5mm)
  • 2pcs F608ZZ flanged bearings (8mm x 22mm x 7mm)
  • ~10pcs N52 12mm X 2mm Super Strong Round Disc Magnets Rare Earth Neodymium magnet
  • 3pcs M5x30-50 bolts and nuts
  • 1pcs M4x30 screw and nut
  • 2pcs M3x15 Hex socket screws
  • 5pcs M3x20 Hex socket screws
  • 5pcs M3 nuts
  • 2pcs M3 self-locking nuts

Also you need to buy Sharpening Stones from Apex, like this

In a future I plan to make stones by myself, using printed blanks, glass and sandpaper.

Vallis Schröteri (Schroter's Valley) on the Moon

Schroter's Valley, frequently known by the Latinized name Valed on a rise of continental ground, sometimes called the Aristarchus plateau, that is surrounded by the Oceanus Procellarum to the south and west and the Mare Imbrium to the northwest. At the southern edge of this rise are the craters Aristarchus and Herodotus. (information from :WIKI)

The selenographic coordinates of this valley are 26.2°N 50.8°W.

DEM data: http://wms.lroc.asu.edu/lroc/view_rdr/WAC_GLD100

Exaggeration factor : 3x

SchroterValley_L_20-20_0.5_3x.stl, SchroterValley_S_20-20_0.5_3x.stl --> high resolution
SchroterValley_L_20-20_1.0_3x.stl, SchroterValley_S_20-20_1.0_3x.stl --> low resolution

月球表面的"施勒特爾月谷"，常稱作蛇谷。

author: Leslie13

description.text:
I printed the original model earlier this year and was very happy. As I've learnt more about the design software and 3D Printing I've wanted to put more detail into this model. I've been using stills from a recent eBay auction for one of the original Liberators from the BBC so have been able to verify some of finer design details. I'd like to say this model would not have been possible without zeframs work on the original. I've included all parts in this list to make a Liberator, if it doesn't say 'new' its directly from zeframs model. Many thanks again for your design.

I hope you have fun printing this, the engine lines are done using white filament which fits in the holes and groves in the new model. It's a bit fiddly but definitely sets the model off.

I printed the nacelles in 10% infill otherwise they can get quite heavy and not hang right off of the fuselage.

Following a request to have the engine light up I have refined the design a little. I've added a new rear section and hollow engine globes. I used 12v LED lighting and a 12v type N battery and holder to make this work along with a small 555 based flashing circuit. It all goes together well and just means the rear would need swapping out to give you that option. To switch mine on I need to pull the engine globe piece off of the rear, switch it on and return it to the model. I've included pictures of the 12v LED strip and how I wired it up. Feel free to ask any questions you may have.

Another mod has been requestd and now there are two new files. These are for the nacelle fronts and front fuselage section with 1.5mm holes in to take metal rods instead of the printed tips. This makes it closer to the original Liberator.

To print you will need:
1 each of all of the Fuselage sections - choose the Mk2 rear section if you want the engine to light up as there is room for a battery and electronics to make this happen.
2 engine globes - choose the hollow ones if you want to have the engine light up and remember to put the wire in half way through the printing of the holes.
3 each of all of the Nacelle sections
3 struts
19 pins
1 stand
Some white filament for the engine

Requirement

Adjustment:
Every holes may need to be drill a little (While designing it I had considered it was best too tight than too loose)

Raspberry support is designed for Raspberry 2, but should work with all version.

Camera support was designed for this camera (lens was changed) :

If you don't like fisheye, you can change the lens here :

I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of the Andrastian Chantry) adding a circular base. Then, I modelled the amulet in Blender.

The Chantry is the dominant religious organization in Thedas. It is based on the Chant of Light, a series of teachings written by Andraste, the prophet of the Maker, and was founded by Kordillus Drakon, the first emperor of Orlais. The Chantry's followers are known as Andrastians. The Chantry's goal is to spread the Chant of Light to all four corners of the world and to all races. Once all peoples have accepted the Chant and practice its teachings, the Maker will return and restore the world to its former glory.

I broke a side latch on my kitchen window while replacing the spiral balances. This is a replacement for the LEFT HAND latch. If you need the right hand latch you can mirror the part while slicing.
Should you too have a house with these elderly Alcan aluminum windows, I hope this is of use to you. If you use it, please let me know by posting a "make" or comment. Feedback always welcome.

Watch out for the spring when removing the old part from the window!

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0A (Repetier)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Slice with 3 perimeters for strength. (in Slic3r, 3 top & bottom layers, 3 perimeters)
Designed to be printed in ABS for durability. PLA may be too brittle, YMMV.
Supports ARE required.
The only post-print work should be to remove the support material. This is a bit of a pain due to the underside detail but, apart from that, it's Print'n'Play!

Original part + digital calipers + Tinkercad

title: Green Screen PVC Frame Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a large DIY green screen behind my desk for videos and livestreaming. It is constructed out of 3/4 inch schedule 80 (i.e. grey electrical) PVC pipe.

Though it has a base that prevents it from falling over easily, it also has a bar along the top for mounting clamp lights. Small diameter PVC pipe is a bit bendy at any significant length (above about 1.5 - 2 feet), so the weight of the lights and the screen itself makes it tend to lean away from the wall.

I designed this to hold the screen vertical. One or more can be snapped around the light mounting bar or the vertical pipes on the sides of the screen and then nailed or screwed to the wall to hold the screen vertical, similar to the strap that is included with a flat packed bookshelf.

The small nubs on the round clip are for adding an optional retainer, such as a bread tie or elastic band.

Note: My screen is long enough that it partially covers a nearby window on one end, so there is always going to be a gap between the frame and the wall that wouldn't otherwise be there. I may add a spacer for such situations, but if you need to print one, you can always flip the clip upside down in your slicer (curved bits down), scale the clip on Z so the spacer is the desired height, and then cut off the curved bits. In Cura you'd use the Cut Off Object Bottom field on the Advanced tab.

this is a tripod style bracket for the xbox kinect sensor. this one was designed to fit the sony vaio tap 11 it also has a 14/20 nut embedded in the bottom bracket for tripod use. i prefer to weld the parts together by dragging a soldering iron down the seams but it can be glued together as well. you need a 1" 1/4 20 bolt and nut. i have added larger cord winders to hold the thick kinect cord better. description.text:
I recently designed a power distribution board holder for my Force 2 Frames Nano 130 FPV racing quadcopter. I wanted to mount it below the frame to allow more room for wiring and to lower the overall CG of the quad.

I decided something similar would be nice on some of my other quads, so I redesigned it to work with most common PDBs and Flight controllers.

I've included printable STL files for the DemonCore PDB, the Flip32 FC, and a generic PDB.

I've also included the OpenSCAD file which can be easily modified for other PDBs, FCs, and various mounting options. Setting the various documented parameters should allow you to produce a holder that will work with your PDB or FC. OpenSCAD is free. Just download, open the scad file, set the parameters, hit render, then export to STL (you should be able to do this even if you don't know OpenSCAD).

Voici une arrivée d'air extérieur pour le ventilateur de buses. L'air dans l'imprimante peut dépasser les 30°C, ce qui bouche les buses. En prenant l'air à l'extérieur environ 20°C, l'arrivée de filament avant les buses est mieux ventilé. Un centreur est positionné sur le ventilateur 40x40 au-dessus des buses. Un autre centreur est disposé au centre du couvercle du bâti pour fixer le tuyau. Le tuyau est attaché avec des colliers. Le tuyau est un tuyau de ventilation d'air, métallique, souple et de diamètre 80mm. La longueur du tuyau permet l'ouverture du couvercle pour une ventilation de l'intérieur de la K8400 et la prise d'air frais venant de la fenêtre derrière l'imprimante. Sur le centreur haut, j'ai imprimé une grille de ventilateur en la mettant à l'échelle 80x80mm. Vous pouvez aussi enlever le ventilateur 40x40 et mettre un ventilateur 80X80 à l'extérieur sur le centreur.

I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of Akatosh). Then, I modelled the amulet in Blender.

Akatosh, the Dragon God of Time, is the chief deity of the Nine Divines, the official religion of the varying Cyrodiil empires, such as the Septim Empire and the Reman Dynasty. He represents the qualities of endurance, invincibility, and everlasting legitimacy. Along with Lorkhan, he is one of two deities found in every Tamrielic religion. He is generally considered to be the first of the Gods to form in the Beginning Place. After his establishment, other spirits followed his example, and the various pantheons of the world emerged. Akatosh is considered the god-defender of the Empire.

description.text: In order to provide children and teens with a fun, customizable opportunity to investigate the relationship between objects, meaning, and value, this Thing provides a template on which students can build their own rings, pendants, bracelets, etc.

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

50-100 microns, whichever you prefer.

Infill:

20-30%

If you choose to pursue this project as an entrepreneurial endeavor, then you and your students can post-process your customized pieces to prepare them for casting in order to create a beautiful, layer-free finish.

In TinkerCad

Although TinkerCad is likely the simplest of CAD software packages available, it provides many options. Using the basic 3D shape templates provided, one can produce a wide array of jewelry designs.

Project: Custom Jewelry-Making for Kids

By completing this project, participants will gain an understanding of the relationship between value and meaning, as well as the differences in between aesthetic and utility. Through discussions, show-and-tell activities, hand-drawing, and CAD drawing, participants will be asked to apply their new knowledge by customizing a jewelry piece. This project culminates in the presentation of student projects, wherein each student describes and explains the unique features and valuable qualities (aesthetic and/or practical) associated with their piece. If possible, students should prototype jewelry using a D printer and cold-cast their final pieces in order to be kept and worn by the student or auctioned for charity.

This project can be administered as an art, entrepreneurship, or social studies project. IT is important for the instructor to adjust their presentation of this activity according to the needs and interests of their students as well as any logistical constraints in the educational environment.

Tool holder which can be screwed to your wall.

description.text: This is based off of the very excellent Foam Dart Pistol from vik. I couldn't achieve the desired height with the Thing-O-Matic that I wanted, so I modified the design to have a separate muzzle. I added a sight to the muzzle to facilitate putting the two parts securely together. The muzzle piece actually goes on and stays in place without glue, especially with the rubber bands in place. I added the matching sight parts to the back. of the gun, and updated the openscad to have optional mouse ears to keep parts down better. I needed the ears with the ABP, but not with a HBP. You can see the ears on the blue muzzled gun. My wife thought they gave the gun a sci-fi look, so she wanted to keep them. Early testing showed that the firing pin quickly chewed into the front of the barrel. So I added a second set of blocks (that will also work with the original design) that can be glued on additionally, and replaced with wear. They also support rubber stops nicely. I used cut up pieces of a rubber washer. This came about because, I had a lot of trouble printing the pistol at first. Turns out it was mostly due to my ABP on my Thingomatic allowing too much sway. I took off the belt, and have a quasi-HBP now. My prints are much more accurate, especially when printing so tall.

Use the STL files to print the parts, or the openscad file to decide which parts to print, or to add mouse ears to help hold the pieces down. Basically the same as the original Foam Dart Pistol with the following steps:
  • Remove any unwanted mouse ears
  • Trim front sight so that the muzzle sits flush with the barrel, and glue using modeling glue or other adhesive.
    • I also had trouble with the melting of the filament for holding the sear and trigger, so I just opted for modeling glue, and it works out better for me. For assembly see the video here:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=auKLBw5P9bQ

description.text: R2D2 foot for the 3d print full size build. Watch out for captive nuts. 8MM bar for the hinge and 3mm bar for the leg bar (used for 2-3-2 to keep the foot stable in upright). As always, I'm building and sharing as I design so please let me know if you face any issues. The Leg rod is also included in these files, a rod which connects the 6mm fixed bar to the foot to ensure it stands upright and moves to the 18 degree position. Please note the end of the rod is attached once it's fitted using 3mm 40mm bolts and captive nuts which need adding as you glue. The rod is critical to stability and should be printed above 90% infill for strength. I printed mine layer .30, 6 shells and 100% infill. One bar per leg is needed (only posted the right foot and right bar, left one coming soon). The bar attaches to the front fixed 6mm bar in the leg near the shoulder. You'll need some of these also. sourcingmap M3x40mm Hex Socket Head Knurled Cap Screws Bolts Nuts Set 50Pcs https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B015A3CV2Q/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_K2azxbWTKP868. 26/6 Battery Box and Battery Harness added. Here's a video showing the Feet / Leg mechanism for the 2-3-2 conversion. https://youtu.be/O0uImKep5bk The Leg, body and Feet go to 18 degree angle (total 36 degree leg swing), I wanted to test how solid the leg bar could hold the feet. In the video you can see it self supports in 3 leg mode without the third leg, so really pleased. Can stand up without support also on 2 leg mode with a little flex. Overall delighted. Now to automate the whole thing.... Please Note the remaining design will be posted on Astromech.net (free to join and a great community). Also check out the Patreon page for links to the files. I will alway share all files for free and the original source files. I've now finished a complete revision of all the models, version 2 (all shared freely and openly), check https://www.patreon.com/mrbaddeley for links.

comments.text: Hi, I used razor scooter motors for mine. Note this was for version 2. Version 1 was just a static. Link to the latest files is via my Patreon page, all files shared through a OneDrive share and available openly and freely in the spirit of the R2 builders club.

comments.text: Thanks, I was looking at the razor scooter motors myself. Did you buy/find the scooters or just buy the motors? I tried to just buy the motors but they want a UPC code. I tried to grab one from Walmart but either I didn't get the right code or I looked at the wrong box.
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: Got them from eBay, e100 chain motors.
comments.author: dlevans

comments.text: Hello. Is there a photo of how the footA frame should look when its done. I'm new to building R2 and I want to do it right the first time. Or is there a photo of the inside to help figure out ware parts go?
comments.author: Granutan117

comments.text: Excellent.  Any idea when those new foot shells will be done (just curious)?
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text: Do you have the inner dimensions of these?  Will these shells work in conjunction with the foot drives that you'll be releasing publicly soon?
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text: I'm redesigning the skins to fit the new drives. Technically these will fit the new drives (inner space) however the fixings and getting them over the motor would be a challenge, possible, but challenging. New designs will screw onto the new drive.
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text:
hi! how much infill do you recommend for these parts ?
thanks for the incredible job?
you are an artist!!
comments.author: Tevans

comments.text: Hiya, I did around 15 or 20% infill for virtually all parts except some of the heavy load bearing frame sections where I did 50+
comments.author: Tevans

comments.text: Great Build! But how i can print the center foot?
comments.author: warto

comments.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608106 It's on the lift leg files, just print the foot and ankle.
comments.author: warto

comments.text: great!! many thx
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: The centre foot files are on the old centre leg lift mechanism. Just print out the centre leg and foot. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608106
comments.author: warto

comments.text: The centre foot files are on the old centre leg lift mechanism. Just print out the centre leg and foot. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608106
comments.author: warto

comments.text: The centre foot files are on the old centre leg lift mechanism. Just print out the centre leg and foot. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608106
comments.author: warto

comments.text: Never mind. :) got it figured out
comments.author: sitpadeshu

comments.text: i'm printing this shell and found that there are a couple of pieces missing. The front and back pieces with the corners aren't in the files.
comments.author: sitpadeshu

comments.text: Any chance you have the complete foot in an STL file?
comments.author: rrsalina

comments.text: Hiya. all my original designs are also shared, there's a link in the Dome description to the 123d design files. From this you can cut / slice or create as you need (123D design is free to download and fairly easy to use). Hope this helps.
comments.author: rrsalina

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: Pls you can to help me? I don´t know to built the battery box I have printed the piezes but i don´t know to glue this
comments.author: SUSAO69

comments.text: I am in the process of printing one of these foot shells.  Can you please explain how you are securing your foot motor holder to the shell itself?
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text: Hi, there's space for 4 captive nuts on the top of the shell (need futtung during assembly), this gives 4 bolt holes for a frame. additionally the battery box has open space to give as much room as poss for any drive system. The plan is to create options for motor frames (and caster frames or printed wheels) which bolt to the top of the foot with the captive nuts. I'm close to designing one for mine but I wanted to give options as people may use different motors etc.
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text: Do you know if these foot motor covers will work in conjunction with with the 'A&A foot motor holders'?
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: I've designed them for a fully 3D printed R2, so not sure on compatibility with the club spec / other designs. The outer dimensions and accuracy I'm confident with but internal fitting and compatibility has not been tested or designed for club spec. That said, I've left as much space free and added the fixing to allow fitting or modification of other foot frames where possible.
comments.author: flyfast

comments.text: Is this to the R2 Builders specs? If so, is the CSL or CSR? I would love to print these and they look exceptional.
comments.author: morgenes

comments.text: Hi, I've used CSR blueprints for all the dimensions, they're not club spec from a build perspective (holes / screws may not match and assembly is different) but accuracy should match full club spec as the build and parts all fit together.
comments.author: morgenes

comments.text: Looks really good
comments.author: Porscher

comments.text: Hello, this is only the cover ? i don't see the mechanical parts: motor and wheels holders etc.
comments.author: bobbyshomerul

comments.text: Hi, still work in progress, this is the skin with the frame for a 2-3-2 conversion and appropriate holes etc for cables. The Motor, drive, wheels and frame I'm making modular so it can accomodate both castors, motorised and static. there's 4 4mm bolts in the corner to add whichever frame is needed.
comments.author: bobbyshomerul

This is a prototype for an optimized (torsionally stable) support structure.

It can be mounted on a snap fit open base or a closed hinge type base.

It can be embedded into wall structures for reinforcement.

It can be used as a lateral support or a lever between two press fit base parts.

Possible uses: Airplane wing strut, building support, earthquake stable support, lever, hinge part.

Design

Modeled using Truspace 7.6 for printing on a Form1 or Afina

Design optimized in MeshMixer

Middle crossover is "half lapped" for improved strength without loss of torsional strength.

title: Adjustable endstop for modified Z-axis on ShenzenTech Printer

description.text:
A small modification to add an adjustable Z-Endstop to my ShenzenTech Printer.

NB: The thumbnails show the first version of the classic Shenzentech's motor plate; the new version is better sized (longer on X axis and shorter on Z) and the smooth rod is aligned with the screw rod.

Printer:

Prusa i3 China Derivated

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

0.40%

Holes adjustment

Adjustment:
Every holes may need to be drill a little (While designing it I had considered it was best too tight than too loose)

Parts needed:

2x longer 3mm screw for the fixation to the X-carriage
(for the original ShenzenTech X-carriage 22mm is OK)
1x 5mm screw for the adjustment screw.

title: Hot-air retainer support for Rostock Max

description.text: If you're like me you may have found that warm air blowing across the heated-bed seems to help keep printed parts from lifting off the printing surface.  In order to keep the heat localized a piece of cardboard is placed around the periphery of the heated bed.  The problem with simply propping the cardboard in place is that it can shift position and jam under the Rostock Max cheapskates- this can be seen in one of the pictures posted.  This device is designed to position and support this piece of cardboard.

comments.text: Awesome Idea!! I was thinking about making a similar device with the same intention (though I wanted to simply trap heat and prevent drafts, don't know if I'd chance blowing warm air on the bed).

comments.text: This is not what you want to do.  By constraining the leadscrew, any variation in the screw (e.g bends) will be transmitted to the bed and part.  Look on the forums for any of the MB clones.  You'll see plenty advice for removing the top bearing when the cloner's add them and the result are better prints.
comments.author: dcullen

comments.text: So you are saying not to stabilize the Z axis leadscrew?
comments.author: dcullen

comments.text: Yep.   Use an Astrosyn stepper isolator and make sure that your rods are straight and locked down.  If you constrain both ends of the leadscrew then any lateral misalignment is forced into the print bed.  You want the lead screw to cause only Z-axis movement.
comments.author: Stouffy

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
While walking around a biology class last year I noticed many students trying to use their iPads to take pictures through the eyepiece of their microscopes. While it is possible to get good images this way, it is incredibly difficult. This is my attempt to make it possible without as much luck needed.

Being able to rest your iPad on a surface and then having two points to press against makes it much easier to keep the camera aligned looking through the eyepiece.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I specifically didn't upload the models on a single build plate. I found the screws broke very easily while de-plating. I recommend printing them separate from the main piece with more perimeters and/or a higher infill. Conversely you can just be extra careful.

You will obviously need to print two copies of the screw.

No clean-up is needed. I originally designed an adapter for a naked iPad Air, but decided we now have several models of iPads in our school and most have cases. This design allows you to adjust for the particular iPad/case combination.

Start by flipping the iPad so you can see the camera. Adjust the screws so that the camera is as close to the center of the hole as you can get it. Then mount the adapter to your microscope. You will need a little fine tuning and practice in order to capture some really nice images. The screws need to be adjusted slightly and/or you need to change move the iPad slightly so that your image is in a circle with a nice crisp edge to ensure the maximum field of view. Only a little practice is needed to get good images.

I designed this in Tinkercad. It involved quite a bit of trial and error. You'll notice, for example, that the adapter keeps the iPad from getting too close to the eye piece. I learned that the vignetting gets worse the closer the camera lens is to the microscope.

The screws are positioned such that they should not press any of the iPad's buttons while in use. I designed this with the iPad Air and the Air 2 in mind. So, I can't confirm this will not be a problem for the iPad Pro or older iPad models. If it is you can easily edit my model on Tinkercad.

Our student microscopes have an eyepiece with a 28.5 mm diameter. In Tinkercad I used a 29 mm hole and it fits with a very nice level of tightness. If you change my design you'll still need to keep the iPad to be 10-15 mm away from the eyepiece for optimal viewing.

The nut and bolt came from mike_linus' Nut Job. I imported the stl files into Tinkercad and mounted the nuts as seen and then added wings to the bolt to make it easier to turn. Although in retrospect, the wings aren't really needed.

Tinkercad Models:

  • Main Stand
  • Screws
NGSS

In a traditional biology class students often start learning about mitosis by looking at styalized/simplified pictures and they learn the names of the different stages. This leads to memorization without any real understanding. It would be much better to have students start by conducting investigations similar to the scientists who first described the process.

In a very real sense, to “learn” the meaning of a new phrase or term requires that one “reinvent” or re-create the concept.” (Lawson, 1995)

I propose having students look at well prepared specimens of onion root tips and have them look for patterns and differences. They should be able to see differences and sequence what they see. From this, the idea of cell division can be constructed in large part by the students themselves. The precise/accepted language can be introduced later. Objectives
  • Students will begin to recognize the major stages in cell division
  • Students will be able to put into the correct sequence a number of pictures showing a cell at various points undergoing mitosis.
    • Audiences
  • High school students
    • Subjects
  • Biology
    • Skills/Standards
  • NGSS - Disciplinary Core Ideas
    • LS1.A: Structure and Function
    • LS1.B: Growth and Development of Organisms
  • NGSS - Scientific and Engineering Practices
    • Asking Questions
    • Developing and using models
    • Analyzing and Interpreting Data
  • NGSS Crosscutting Concepts
    • Patterns
    • Scale, proportion, and quantity
    • Structure and Function

• Have students in pairs photograph three to four areas on an onion root tip cross section at 400x magnification (using the 40x objective lens)
  • In whole class discussion, ask students what they see? If possible have students share some of their pictures with the class with a projector or large computer screen. From this discussion you want to lead them to the realization that the different cells they see represent different points in a sequence. They should see changes in:
    • Nucleus
    • DNA
    • Chromosomes
  • With their partners, have students crop out individual cells that look different and try to sequence them. Apps that might be good for this:
    • Notability
    • Keynote
  • Have pairs of students join each other (into groups of four) to share their pictures with each other. Ask such questions as:
    • Are all of these different points in the sequence?
    • What do you think is happening?
    • Can you identify some “major” stages? Try to identify 4-6.
  • Have students create sketches of their stages. They can also use an app like Adobe Ideas to trace the cell. Adobe Ideas uses layers, so the photo can be removed leaving just the sketch.
  • Groups share results with the class.
  • Draw student attention to the mitosis section in their textbooks and have them draw parallels between their sequence and the stages traditionally shown.
    • Are all the traditional stages represented? Why not?
    • Which if any are missing? Why?
    • Duration
    2 - 3 class periods

Preparation
  • Skills/Knowledge Required:
    • Students should already be familiar with basic cell structure
    • Students should know the basics of DNA and chromosomes
    • Students should have a basic understanding of microscope use
  • Stuff Needed:
    • One microscope per pair of students
    • One iPad microscope adapter and iPad per pair of students
    • Prepared onion root tip slides stained to show mitosis
• Lawson, A. E. (1995). Science teaching and the development of thinking. Belmont, CA: Wadsworth Pub.

description.text:
A protective case for the back side of the Interface 1bis ver. 4c for the Sinclair ZX Spectrum.

Not a complete enclosing box, but for now rather designed to protect the back side against accidental shorts and static when my kids use the computer.

Version 3 onwards have enough room inside them that you can leave the optional I2C mounted inside, if like me you bought it for future use (pay attention to how the loose connector is placed to avoid shorts). Note: No hole for the cable has been designed in yet.

Version 4.1 should be used instead of version 3. It has a slightly reinforced bottom holding flap and some cosmetic improvements.

Version 4.2b has a hole for the I2C cable to exit through, and somewhat rounded corners. If you want to be able to pull the I2C cable out through the case or store it inside at will, this is the version you want.

Sketchup source and earlier versions included. Version 1 is not quite deep enough for the capacitors on the 4c, and the holding arms are too thin and fragile -- but if you prefer a flush back side this may be a better starting point for modification. Version 2 works fine without the I2C cable mounted (not tested with it), and has a bit more robust bottom, however without the bottom holding flap and with a few holes a bit larger than optimal.

Interface 1bis home page: https://sites.google.com/site/interface1bis/

Note for the guy selling printed versions of this case: I have absolutely no problem with you earning a bit using my design, and once you add a simple line along "Designed by ZeAllan; source files available here:...." to your sales post, I am also happy to know that in return for getting these files for free you are honouring your part of the license under which you are allowed to sell your printed copies.
Oh, and also, you might want to state that this is designed for version 4c if the interface since other versions might not fit the case, and angry customers are not worth it. ;-)

Notes:

Sliced for PLA using .24 layers, and -0.12 in Slic3r's XY Size Compensation to compensate for hole overflow. Support enabled for the joystick port part.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Y Axis Pulley

description.text:
The bearings on my Y idler pulley are shot big time and my 3D store is taking forever to get a replacement. I designed this to get me by although I know it's not going to last a long time. Two files because I used some Lubriplate between the sleeve and pulley so had to have it apart anyhow. White lithium should work fine... I added one flat washer between the hex screw and sleeve (right hand side looking down) and two washers on the left between the sleeve and bracket on the front cross member.
Just to let you know, I have the popular Z Brace mod and zip tied Y pulley. When I put a new zip tie on the hex screw it didn't like the extra tension against the sleeve and pulley (barked like a dog with rapid Y movements) so I took it off until I finally get an actual pulley with ball bearings. Hopefully this will get you by in a pinch like it has me. For some reason my need for a warranty part and be able to complete 3D Hubs orders is not high on my 3D store's list of priorities (He'll probably read this -hopefully)
https://www.3dhubs.com/salt-lake-city/hubs/wasatch-brian

RepRap

Printer:

Duplicator i3

No

No

0.070 (70 micron)

100%`

I decided to take a picture of the pulley installed but looking at it, the print quality sucks then I remembered that was the reason I needed it in the first place. Printed with the wobbling worn out Y pulley. Will keep an extra in my spare parts box. Almost have another printer in there :-)

Here's the link to the parts (pack of 5 for $10.99) why was I waiting for my 3D printer store to get one in... FWIW, there's a 3D printer seller in Amsterdam (I think) that wanted $22.00 to ship me one of these...
Hard to remember what life was like without my 3D printer. Maybe I'll try to go a day or two without a cell phone too lol

title: Winch Handle Key
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The filler caps for water and fuel on my boat use a winch handle to undo them, but you need several turns to undo them, which is basically not possible with a 1 foot long handle! So I needed something smaller. I found the original filler cap wrench by Beoga, but the handle was still too big, so I remixed it with a smaller key style handle.

Just to add, it floats if you drop it overboard as well, which is better than the winch handle does!

Printer:

XYZ Davinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've made a print vertically and horizontally (so that the grain is across the key or up/down the key) and it does't seem to make a lot of difference to the strength, they are both good enough :)

I tend to print the key upright with support for the lugs only and support only from the bed as this seems the neatest route, but if you slowed the print down it ought to print with no support at all (I am impatient and print it at 100mm/s!)

title: Bionic optimized toilette paper roll holder

description.text:
This project shows the way how to design a bionic optimized part. That means that only structure is created, which is important for the stiffness at choosen loadsteps. The part in this project is an optimized toilette paper roll holder. With structural optimization you are able to save material and increase your design process.

please see attached pdf!

MakerEdChallenge2

Printer:

RigidBot Big

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

22%

Notes:

please see attached pdf!

Any tips and tricks are written in the attached file, so feel free to download it! The pdf file includes the step by step guidance in english and german version.

Easily setup and optimize design -> wrap it -> print it!

please see attached pdf!

Project: bionic optimized toilette paper roll holder

Project name: The name of the part includes all relevant information ;)
Overview & Background: I will learn to understand the whole process of innovative CAE driven product design.

Objectives: Students will learn how to create a bionical design the fastest way. The keyword is “Lightweight” as shown by our nature. You will learn how easy it is to save material and stiffen your parts with only a few klicks. As addition: english students could learn a little bit of german language and german students could improve their english skills ;)

Audiences: Everyone can reproduce this project. Admittedly, prefered for Highschool students with technical background. You only need a student license from Altair Inc. (in Germany Altair Engineering GmbH), which you can easily get from the company, just ask there. A technical background would be nice but not necessary. If you are interested in engineering, physics, maths or science, you are able to reproduce this project!

Subjects: maths, physics, engineering, science, structural mechanics, design

Skills learned: analyze structural problem and solve them with easy handling in CAE-tools

Standards:
National Science Education Standards Grades 9-12 (ages 14-18)
• CONTENT STANDARD A: Science as Inquiry
As a result of activities, all students should develop
o Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry
• CONTENT STANDARD B: Physical Science
As a result of their activities, all students should develop understanding of
o Motions and forces
• CONTENT STANDARD E: Science and Technology
As a result of activities, all students should develop
o Abilities of technological design
o Understandings about science and technology
• CONTENT STANDARD F: Science in Personal and Social Perspectives
As a result of activities, all students should develop understanding of
o Science and technology in local, national, and global challenges
• CONTENT STANDARD G: History and Nature of Science
As a result of activities, all students should develop understanding of
o Historical perspectives

Standards for Technological Literacy - All Ages
• The Nature of Technology
o Standard 1: Students will develop an understanding of the characteristics and scope of technology.
• Technology and Society
o Standard 4: Students will develop an understanding of the cultural, social,
economic, and political effects of technology.
o Standard 5: Students will develop an understanding of the effects of
technology on the environment.
o Standard 6: Students will develop an understanding of the role of society in
the development and use of technology.
o Standard 7: Students will develop an understanding of the influence of technology on history.
• Design
o Standard 8: Students will develop an understanding of the attributes of
design.
o Standard 9: Students will develop an understanding of engineering design.
o Standard 10: Students will develop an understanding of the role of
troubleshooting, research and development, invention and innovation, and
experimentation in problem solving.
• Abilities for a Technological World
o Standard 11: Students will develop abilities to apply the design process.
• The Designed World
o Standard 20: Students will develop an understanding of and be able to select
and use structural optimization technologies.

Lesson/Activity: Please see all informations in the attached pdf file. There is a step by step manual with all tips and tricks from my experience knowledge.

• Setup the optimization model
• Discuss different types of restrictions
o Vary fixing point positions
o Vary symmetry
o Vary manufacturing constraints
o Vary thicknesses
• Analyse the generated design
o Identify critical areas
o Identify areas to delete
• Discuss geometry
o Loadpaths
o Square
o Thickness
• Discuss physics
o Force
o Load
o Reaction
o Equilibrium
o Tension
o Compression
o Strength
• Factors that engineers consider when designing bridges
o Structural efficiency
o Cost efficiency
o Aesthetics
o Stiffness
o Printability
• Guide students through selecting/creating a model, either work in teams or individually. Set model specifications and constraints, these will depend on your time and resources:
o Minimum /maximum thicknesses
o Maximum amount of filament to be used to 3D print the design
o Minimum amount of weight the holder should hold
• Students 3D print and mounting their design
• Supervise and assess students testing their design

Duration: Setup the optimization model: 0,5 – 2 hours
Optimization run: depends on the choosen parameters (explained in pdf file)
Wraping: 0,5 – 2 hours (depends on your creativity and desired quality)
Setup printing parameters: 0,5 – 1 hours
Printing time: 36 hours stated out by Cura with explained parameters

Preparation: Students should only be interested in engineering stuff. You need the student lincense for Inspire/Hypermesh (contact Altair inc.), Cura or any other C-Code generator and last but not least of course a 3D printer ;)

References: economics literature

Rubric & Assessment: Student should have setup the optimization problem in Inspire and interpret the results right. In the wraping-section you can see, if the students come to a good compromise between optimization result and wraped design. In the first two steps the students are learning very much about lightweight design and CAE driven design processes, what is very important for their future as engineer or designer.
By the end of the project the student will have a designed, 3D printed, and tested a bionic toilette paper roll holder.
Assessment Criteria:
• Did the students design meet the minimum requirements:
o Length
o Width
o Hold minimum weight
o Did not exceed the maximum allocation of 3D printer filament
• Can the student identify features of their design:
o Type of loadpaths (tensile / compression bar)
o Use of geometric shapes
o Locate points of force, load, reaction, equilibrium, tension, compression, and strength

Handouts & Assets: as oftener mentioned -> attached pdf file!!!

title: Reimagining the Plain and the Mundane: Home Edition

description.text:
The Bowl-tastic Cereal System is a product of the Design Thinking process. Products like this can be made by taking students through the DT process, starting with creating the How Might We question, brainstorming prototypes, sketching, and then finally building their products using Tinkercad. Both the bowl and the spoon are the products of the lesson: Re-imagining the Plain and Mundane: Home Edition.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online
Bowl: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/20UiDNsOgIn
Spoon: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1622518
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WTeGHrQP4-E" ></iframe>

The goal of this activity and lesson is to take students through the design thinking process to rethink the possibilities for everyday household items. What are the inadequacies of the home? How can home product design be improved? Let’s change the world with simple designs and products, printed out and prototyped with the Makerbot Replicator!

Once they have their How Might We question individuals will complete the following for their question (adapted from Brainstorm in a Box): (15 min)
Give your idea a title.
Explain your idea in one sentence.
Identify the need or problem you are trying to solve.
Identify who will benefit from your idea. Vote :
Post the idea sheets around the room and hand out three color stickers (red, blue, and green)
Blue = doable
Green = maybe
Red = Nope
Students then take their stickers and place them by all of their different ideas. (10 min)
Students return to their original small group and discuss and choose one idea to continue with as a group. They should be sure to consider the feasibility and the size of the audience that will benefit. Explain to the whole group that it is encouraged for the whole group to ask questions for clarification. Model this by asking a group how might we do this? Why might we do this? Begin sketching prototype
Group members may approach the problem in different ways. Each student should sketch their solution to the problem. Group members may collaborate on a solution if desired. Day 3 - ?: Begin Tinkercad Students use Tinkercad to develop the prototypes of their ideas. At this point, students may need to print out their designs and redesign several times before settling on their final solution.

• Standards
  • MS-ETS1-1
  • MS-ETS1-2
  • MS-ETS1-3
  • MS-ETS1-4

In the end, students should have designed and printed an original piece that is the solution to the How Might We question they brainstormed in the beginning. You can use the below rubric to assess their level of depth in regards to problem solving. Use this for assessing student work:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/16QYwIwyaVBEUYYjVeR5rHoIcUGuI-AGGf3payb7GTMM/edit#gid=0

author: Farnomat

description.text:
I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of the Imperials). Then, I modelled the pendant in Blender.

Also known as Cyrodiils, Cyrodilics, Cyro-Nordics and Imperial Cyrods, the well-educated and well-spoken Imperials are the natives of the civilized, cosmopolitan province of Cyrodiil. Imperials are also known for the discipline and training of their citizen armies, and their respect for the rule of law. Though physically less imposing than the other races, the Imperials have proved to be shrewd diplomats and traders, and these traits, along with their remarkable skill and training as light infantry, have enabled them to subdue all the other nations and races and erect the monument to peace and prosperity that comprises the Glorious Empire. Their hegemony has waxed and waned throughout the eras, and most historians refer to three distinct Empires, the ends of which each mark a new epoch in Tamrielic history.

title: Mobile phone support for car using CD slot

description.text:
I made this to be able to see/use my Samsung galaxy S6 while driving. The phone holder can turn to face driver/passenger.

It is a 3 part design :

  • CD Slot insert (should be compatible with most cars, designed for and tested with Audi A4 )
  • Phone holder ( fits perfectly with my Galaxy S6+case, may need some rework/scaling for other models)

description.text:
This wax seal was inspired by a seal impression from the House of Tiles in Lerna as seen here:
http://antiquatedantiquarian.blogspot.com/2015/04/the-minoans-seals-and-sealings.html

It was trickier to get a good impression than I thought, and I tried about a dozen times before I got the so-so one in the picture. There are a lot of good tutorials for using wax seals on Youtube. It also helps to dunk the seal in ice water for a few seconds before using.

It can be used with the ring base or stamp base. The ring base is approximately size 10, per my understanding of ring sizes.

Printer:

Polyprinter 229

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

70%

Infill:

12.5%

Notes:

When I printed this with the support material set to be used for angles over 45 degrees, it didn't print with support material, but wound up with some scraggly ends at the top of the ring, so it might be worth trying it with a lower angle.
On a previous version, the wax kept get stuck in the seal. For this version I brushed a little acetone over the impression surface and let it sit over night, and it seems like it did the trick.

print_settings.Notes:: I created the model to be .5 tall. This means one layer of .25 for the razors and wire and another layer on top to sort of reinforce and fuse them. Turned out well for me and prints very quickly. It may be advisable to lower your print speed to about 70-80% to ensure each little piece of "razor" actually fuses together and doesn't end up looking like bow ties.

description.text:
Hello folks! I've been building some scenery and obstacles for my Warmachine games and decided to see if I could model a razor wire substitute that would actually print easily and fast. This prints a very long section that can be cut to any lengths needed.

As you can see in the closeup of the 3d model, I made sure to include an emulation of the wire reinforcement that some of the better real razor wires have. This was partially because I am a stickler for details, but also helps make the wire stay in place when you want it to. With that said, it also makes it more fragile. But I have a solution!

If you soak the wire in moderately warm water, it becomes much more accepting to bending and twisting. Then, you can twist it around an object such as a marker or similar cylindrical item and you will end up with a nice coiled section of razor wire.

Happy modelling, folks!

This will likely be a good cheap alternative to some of the other razor wire options people have been using for WMH, 40K, and any other miniatures gaming/modeling/dioramas. As much as I love the brass laser cut stuff they make, you can actually cut yourself on it and it is very expensive. The other option I found was the wire around a wire method you see in the picture above and I really don't find it very convincing.If you make one and use it, please post a picture! I'd love to see what interesting things people will use it for.

Also check out the thing by OneBitPixel
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1035005
I sadly noticed his after I created my own! Give him some love for coming up with the idea first.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Notes:

I created the model to be .5 tall. This means one layer of .25 for the razors and wire and another layer on top to sort of reinforce and fuse them. Turned out well for me and prints very quickly. It may be advisable to lower your print speed to about 70-80% to ensure each little piece of "razor" actually fuses together and doesn't end up looking like bow ties.

  1. Print with Ninjaflex or similar flexible filament
  2. Affix neopixel to mount using clear flexible adhesive, found at most hardware stores
  3. Sew mount to underside of cloth or to the top of a detachable backing layer of cloth.
  4. Embroidery or heavy stitching will allow more of the Neopixel's light to bleed-through the cloth. This is useful for making glowing patterns.
